introduction.p: The number e is essential for many advanced topics, and it is often called the natural base.natural base It may seem strange to use an irrational number as the base for exponential functions, but just as the irrational number \pi arises naturally in geometry, so does e arise in calculus and its applications. At the end of this section we'll look at a specific case of how base e occurs, and how its use is connected to the ideas and techniques of calculus.

subsection.title: The Natural Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: Recall that each exponential function with base b has an inverse function, the logarithmic function with the same base. For example, the function ~y=\log_2{(x)}~ is the inverse of the function ~y=2^x. It gives the exponent needed on 2 to give x, so that, for instance, ~\log_2{(16)} = 4~, because ~2^4 = 16.\alert{\text{[TK]}}~~

aside.p: \alert{\text{[TK]}}~~To review logarithmic functions, see Section 7.3 of the textbook.

subsection.p: The base ee\thinspace logarithm of a number x, or \log_ e {(x)}, is called the natural logarithmnatural logarithm of x and is denoted by \ln {(x)}. (Why ln and not nl? The natural logarithm is denoted by ln because it stands for logarithmus naturalis, which is the Latin for natural logarithm.) Here is its official definition.

assemblage.title: The Natural Logarithm
assemblage.p: The natural logarithm is the logarithm base e. \blert{\ln {(x)} = \log_{e}{(x)}, ~~~~ x\gt 0}

subsection.p: The natural logarithm of x is the exponent to which e must be raised to produce x. For example, the natural logarithm of 10, or \ln {(10)}, is the solution of the equation e^y = 10 You can verify on your calculator that e^{\alert{2.3}} ~~ \approx 10 ~~ \text{ or } ~~ \ln {(10)} \approx \alert{2.3}

As is the case with exponential and log functions with other bases, the natural log functionnatural log function, y= \ln {(x)}, and the natural exponential function, f(x) = e^x, undo each other, so they are inverse functions. (This is why many calculators use 2nd LN to indicate e^x.)

From the graph of g(x) = \ln {(x)} you can make the following observations. ~\alert{\text{[TK]}}~~

The natural logs of negative numbers and zero are undefined.
The natural log of a number greater than 1 is positive, while the logs of numbers between 0 and 1 are negative.

solution.p: We must solve the equation ~10 = \dfrac{20}{1 + 5e^{-0.4t}}~ for t. To begin, we multiply both sides of the equation by the denominator, 1 + 5e^{-0.4t}, to get 1 + 5e^{-0.4t} = \dfrac{20}{10} = 2 Then we isolate the power, e^{-kt}, as follows: 1 + 5e^{-0.4t} \amp = 2 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Subtract 1 from both sides, then divide by 5.}} e^{-0.4kt} \amp = 0.2 Next, we take the natural logarithm of both sides to get \ln {(e^{-0.4t})} = \ln{(0.2)} and recall that \ln {(e^x)} = x to simplify the left side. -0.4t = \ln{(0.2)} Finally, we divide both sides by -0.4 to solve for t. t =\frac{-\ln{(0.2)}}{0.4} \approx 4.02

subsection.p: Sometimes exponential growth is given as a percentage, so for example we might say prices rose by 5% annually. In this case the growth factor is ~b=1+r~, where r is the percentage rate in decimal form. For a percent decrease, ~b=1-r~. \alert{\text{[TK]}}~~

li.p: The growth factor was b = 1 + r = 1.064. The population t years later was P(t) = 768,000 (1.064)^t
We use the formula P(t) = P_0 \cdot e^{kt}, where e^k = 1.064. Solving for k, we find k = \ln {(1.064)} = 0.062 so P(t) = 768,000 e^{0.062t}.

subsection.p: In the Investigation, we saw that the number e arises as the limiting value of the expression \left(1 + \dfrac{1}{n} \right)^n as n increases without bound. The limiting process is one of the fundamental methods of calculus, and helps us understand and analyze other continuous phenomena, such as rates of growth.
